questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass originating within the middle ear. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

Explanation:

 

The CT scan shows a mass located on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, which is typical of a glomus tympanicum, NOT glomus jugulare.

 

Key points:

 

  • Glomus tympanicum arises on the promontory along the course of Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of IX cranial nerve).
  • It is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm.
  • It appears as a red mass behind the intact tympanic membrane, producing a pulsatile red reflex.
  • CT shows a soft tissue mass confined to the middle ear without erosion of the caroticojugular spine.
  • Glomus jugulare, in contrast, originates from the dome of the jugular bulb, grows into the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and typically erodes the caroticojugular spine (the “phelp sign”).

 

In CT image, there is no obvious erosion of the caroticojugular spine, and the mass is confined to the middle ear promontory, confirming glomus tympanicum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect here — because the tumour is limited to the middle ear promontory without signs of extension into the jugular bulb or jugular foramen. There is no caroticojugular spine erosion.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Does not appear as a mass. It causes abnormal bone deposition near the stapes, leading to conductive hearing loss but not a visible mass.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect — because the finding matches glomus tympanicum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A red mass on the promontory behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no erosion of the caroticojugular spine, indicates glomus tympanicum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: IFA supplementation is administered only during pregnancy.
100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient.
Supplementing IFA during the First trimester is adequate.
IFA is started from the second trimester of pregnancy onwards, continues during lactation till 6 months.

questions.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat program aims to reduce anemia through six targeted interventions. Correct regarding administration of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IFA is started from the second trimester of pregnancy onwards, continues during lactation till 6 months

 

  • The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program is a government initiative in India aimed at reducing the prevalence of anemia across various age groups. The strategy follows a "6x6x6" approach – 6 target beneficiaries, 6 Interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.
  • 6 Target beneficiaries - 6 to 59 months old Children; 5 to 9 year old children; 10-19 years old adolescents, reproductive-age women (20-49 year), pregnant women, and lactating mothers.
  • For pregnant women, Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation is a key intervention. IFA is administered starting from the second trimester of pregnancy and is continued throughout the remainder of the pregnancy (180 days). This supplementation is then repeated during the first six months of lactation, also for 180 days. The supplementation is given regardless of the hemoglobin status of the woman, making it a primary preventive measure against anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFA supplementation is administered only during pregnancy: This statement is incorrect because IFA supplementation continues during the first six months of lactation after the pregnancy period, not just during pregnancy.

 

Option B. 100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient: This is incorrect as the recommended course for IFA supplementation in both pregnancy and lactation is 180 days, not 100 days.

 

Option C. Supplementing IFA during the First trimester is adequate: This option is incorrect because IFA supplementation typically begins in the second trimester of pregnancy, not the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program should begin in the second trimester of pregnancy and continue through the first six months of lactation, with a recommended course of 180 days each during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhance fibrin degradation

 

Tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) converts plasminogen to plasmin that breaks the thrombus, which results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus (thrombolysis).

 

Drugs in this class include:

 

S – Streptokinase

 

U – Urokinase

 

R – Reteplase

 

A – Alteplase

 

T – Tenecteplase

 

Indication → Pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability

         Acute ischemic stroke

         Acute MI

 

Overdose of thrombolytics

 

→ Leads to bleeding

 

→ Antidotes: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid [EACA]

                      Tranexamic Acid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibit extrinsic pathway: This is not the mechanism of tPA. The extrinsic pathway involves the activation of clotting factors by tissue factor and is more related to clot formation rather than breakdown.

 

Option B. Inhibits platelet aggregation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Platelet aggregation is inhibited by drugs like aspirin and clopidogrel, not by tPA.

 

Option D. Inhibit clot formation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Inhibition of clot formation is achieved by anticoagulants like heparin and warfarin, whereas tPA is involved in clot breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) enhances fibrin degradation by converting plasminogen to plasmin, leading to the dissolution of blood clots.

questions.text: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the progression from disease to disability? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disease - Impairment - Disability – Handicap

 

The correct sequence of progression from disease to disability is:

 

 

  • This represents the logical progression where a disease process first causes structural or functional abnormalities (impairment), which then restricts activities (disability), ultimately resulting in social disadvantage (handicap).
  • WHO defines impairment as "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function," disability as "restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in a normal manner," and handicap as "disadvantage that limits fulfillment of a normal role."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disease - Disability - Impairment - Handicap: This sequence incorrectly places disability before impairment. Impairment (anatomical/physiological loss) must occur before disability (functional limitation) in the causal pathway.

 

Option C. Disease - Disability - Handicap – Impairment: This sequence incorrectly places impairment at the end. Impairment is the direct consequence of disease and precedes both disability and handicap in the progression.

 

Option D. Disease - Handicap - Disability – Impairment: This sequence reverses the established progression. A specific example illustrates this: an accident (disease) leads to loss of foot (impairment), which causes inability to walk (disability), resulting in unemployment (handicap).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap represents a causal chain where disease causes anatomical/functional changes, leading to activity limitations, and ultimately resulting in social disadvantages that prevent fulfillment of normal roles.

choices.text: Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor
Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein

questions.text: Which of the following criteria must be met to perform a Whipple procedure except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

The Whipple procedure is not contingent on pathologic confirmation of pancreatic head tumor prior to surgery. While biopsy may be performed in certain cases, proceeding directly to surgery without tissue diagnosis is acceptable and sometimes preferred when imaging strongly suggests a resectable pancreatic tumor. Preoperative tissue diagnosis is not mandatory when radiographic findings are consistent with resectable pancreatic cancer and laparotomy is planned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absence of aortic encasement: This is a required criterion for Whipple procedure. Aortic encasement is considered a contraindication to pancreatic resection as it indicates locally advanced disease that would not benefit from surgical resection. Aortic encasement represents unresectable disease.

 

Option C. Absence of liver metastasis: This is a required criterion for Whipple procedure. The presence of liver metastases indicates distant metastatic disease (M1), making the tumor unresectable. Surgery in this setting would not provide survival benefit and is contraindicated.

 

Option D. Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein: This is a required criterion for standard Whipple procedure. Extensive vascular invasion, particularly of the superior mesenteric vessels or portal vein, traditionally defines locally advanced, unresectable disease. Limited vascular involvement may be amenable to vascular resection in specialized centers, but gross invasion indicates unresectability.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While absence of vascular invasion, absence of distant metastases, and absence of aortic encasement are all requirements for Whipple procedure eligibility, pathologic confirmation prior to surgery is not mandatory when imaging strongly suggests a resectable pancreatic head tumor.

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.text: The term "paradoxical carrier" is defined as: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

 

A paradoxical carrier is defined as a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, yet does not exhibit any signs or symptoms of the disease. This situation is paradoxical because the pathogen is typically transmitted directly from an infected patient to a new host, but in this case, it has been passed from one asymptomatic carrier to another. This type of carrier plays a significant role in the epidemiology of certain infectious diseases by perpetuating the transmission cycle without showing clinical symptoms themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period:  This describes an incubatory carrier, who sheds infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. This is different from a paradoxical carrier, as it involves shedding pathogens before symptoms appear.

 

Option C. A person who acquired pathogen from patient:  This does not describe a paradoxical carrier. It refers to a typical transmission scenario where a pathogen is acquired directly from an infected patient, rather than another asymptomatic carrier.

 

Option D. A patient who became a carrier:  This refers to a convalescent carrier or a chronic carrier. A convalescent carrier is someone who continues to shed the disease agent during the recovery period, while a chronic carrier harbors the pathogen long-term. Neither term is synonymous with a paradoxical carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
  • Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.
  • Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.
  • Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with complaints of severe pain, redness, photophobia, and blurring of vision for more than two weeks, not responding to standard treatment. On examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrates and overlying epithelial defects is observed in the affected eye. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba keratitis

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Acanthamoeba keratitis. 
  • The key diagnostic features include:
    • History of contact lens use (most common risk factor)
    • Severe pain that is disproportionate to clinical signs
    • Ring infiltrate in the cornea (pathognomonic sign)
    • Non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy
    • Chronicity of symptoms (over two weeks)

 

Supporting Evidence:

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis presents with characteristic ring infiltrates, central or paracentral, with overlying epithelial defects. The most common predisposing factor is contact lens wear, particularly with improper lens hygiene or exposure to contaminated water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial keratitis:

 

  • Typically responds to antibiotics within days
  • Pain is proportionate to clinical signs
  • Most common organism in contact lens users is Pseudomonas (causes hypopyon ulcer)
  • Does not characteristically form ring infiltrates
  • Usually has quicker onset and progression

 

Option C. Viral keratitis:

 

  • Characterized by dendritic or geographic patterns (herpes simplex)
  • Usually has reduced corneal sensations
  • Responds to antiviral therapy
  • Does not form ring-shaped infiltrates
  • Often has history of recurrence

 

Option D. Fungal keratitis:

 

  • Typically has history of vegetative matter injury
  • Shows feathery margins with satellite lesions
  • Cheesy necrotic appearance of ulcer base
  • May have Wessley immune ring but not typical ring infiltrates as seen in Acanthamoeba
  • Signs are usually more prominent than symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring-shaped stromal infiltrates in a contact lens wearer with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs and non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy is pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

The marked structure is second lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

 

The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and the medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Function of these muscles is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at both the interphalangeal joints.

 

Median Nerve supplies the following intrinsic muscle of hand-

 

  • Thenar Muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis. (Note: The adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve.)
  • Lumbricals: The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals, which flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the index and middle fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN): 

  • This nerve doesn't directly supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. It's mainly responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the forearm.

 

Option C. Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN): 

  • The AIN is a branch of the median nerve but doesn't directly supply the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Instead, it supplies deep muscles in the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus and the radial half of flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: This nerve supply the following intrinsic muscle of hand

 

  • Hypothenar Muscles: Abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, and opponens digiti minimi.
  • Interossei: Both the dorsal and palmar interossei are innervated by the ulnar nerve. They are responsible for abduction and adduction of the fingers, respectively.
  • Third and Fourth Lumbricals: These lumbricals flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the ring and little fingers.
  • Adductor Pollicis: This muscle, as mentioned before, is involved in thumb adduction and is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • Other Hand Muscles: Deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis and all the palmaris brevis muscles are also supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

 

 

MCP = Metacarpophalangeal; IP = Interphalangeal; FDP = Flexor Digitorum Profundus.

choices.text: Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors
Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X

questions.text: What is the most suitable culture medium for Gram-negative coccobacilli isolated from a tender, non-indurated, and irregular genital ulcer? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitale X

 

Explanation:

 

Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X is the most suitable medium for culturing Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of chancroid. This Gram-negative coccobacillus presents with the clinical picture of tender, non-indurated, and irregular genital ulcers. H. ducreyi shows a characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" appearance on microscopy and requires special media for growth. Chocolate agar with isovitalex X  (provides essential nutrients for growth)  is specifically mentioned as one of the appropriate culture media for this fastidious organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thayer-Martin Medium - This medium is primarily used for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis from specimens that may contain mixed flora. While it's used for some Gram-negative diplococci, it's not the optimal medium for H. ducreyi which causes genital ulcers with the described characteristics.

 

Option B. Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors - While H. ducreyi does require X factor (hemin) for growth, simple blood agar with X and V factors is not sufficient. H. ducreyi is extremely fastidious and requires more specialized media such as chocolate agar with isovitalex X for optimal recovery. H. Influenza requires Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors for its growth. 

 

Option D. Tellurite blood agar - This medium is used primarily for isolating Corynebacterium diphtheriae, a Gram-positive bacillus. Tellurite is inhibitory to many organisms but allows C. diphtheriae to grow with characteristic black colonies. This medium is not suitable for the isolation of H. ducreyi from genital ulcers.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Haemophilus ducreyi, the cause of chancroid characterized by tender, non-indurated genital ulcers, is a highly fastidious Gram-negative coccobacillus that requires specialized media such as chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X for successful laboratory culture and diagnosis.

questions.text: Vanillyl mandelic acid is excreted in urine in which of the following conditions?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pheochromocytoma

 

Pheochromocytoma is a tumor of the adrenal glands that can produce excess catecholamines, such as adrenaline and noradrenaline. These catecholamines are metabolized in the body, and one of the metabolites is vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA). Elevated levels of VMA in urine can be indicative of pheochromocytoma. This is because the tumor's excessive catecholamine production leads to increased VMA excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body, not VMA. Therefore, VMA is not excreted in the urine in this condition.

 

Option C. Carcinoid syndrome: Carcinoid syndrome is associated with neuroendocrine tumors called carcinoids. While carcinoid tumors can produce serotonin and other substances, VMA is not a typical marker for this syndrome.

 

Option D. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis is a complication of diabetes characterized by high blood sugar and the production of ketones. It does not involve the excretion of VMA in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of epinephrine is very short, only 2-5 minutes. Epinephrine is catabolized in tissues, by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) to metanephrines.

 

It is then acted upon by monoamine oxidase (MAO). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having the amino group attached to the terminal carbon atom. The major end product is 3-hydroxy-4-methoxy mandelic acid or vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA).

 

Normal level of excretion of VMA is 2–6 mg/24 h. It is increased in pheochromocytoma (epinephrine excess) and in neuroblastoma (norepinephrine excess).

questions.text: Which of the following myeloproliferative disorders is least likely to be associated with massive splenomegaly? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Essential Thrombocytosis (ET)

 

Essential thrombocytosis is the myeloproliferative disorder least likely to be associated with massive splenomegaly. While patients with ET may develop splenomegaly, it is typically mild to moderate in size. The pathophysiology of ET primarily involves excess platelet production rather than the extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis that leads to massive splenomegaly in other MPNs. ET patients can present with erythromelalgia (burning pain and redness in extremities) and thrombotic or hemorrhagic complications, but splenomegaly, when present, is generally modest. The clinical focus in ET is typically on managing thrombotic risk rather than symptoms of splenomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):  Splenomegaly is a hallmark physical finding in CML, occurring in 20-70% of patients. Many patients present with moderate to massive splenomegaly that can extend well below the costal margin, sometimes filling the left side of the abdomen and causing early satiety and abdominal discomfort.
  • Option B. Polycythemia Vera (PV):  PV commonly presents with splenomegaly due to expanded myeloproliferation and increased blood flow. The spleen enlargement can be substantial and is an important clinical feature of the disease, often used in monitoring disease progression.
  • Option D. Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF):  PMF is characterized by progressive, often massive splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. The enlarged spleen in PMF frequently causes significant symptoms including abdominal pain, early satiety, and mechanical discomfort. Spleen size in PMF typically increases as the disease progresses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the myeloproliferative neoplasms, essential thrombocytosis typically presents with the least pronounced splenomegaly, while PMF and CML are most strongly associated with massive splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the “worst headache of my life.” Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

questions.text: Seman's squeeze technique is used for which of the following conditions?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature ejaculation

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a behavioral therapy method used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the man or his partner squeezing the tip of the penis for several seconds right before ejaculation is expected. This helps in delaying ejaculation. The other options do not involve the use of this technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde ejaculation: Retrograde ejaculation refers to the backward flow of semen into the bladder instead of out of the penis.

 

Option B. Erectile dysfunction: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection suitable for intercourse. 

 

Most successful psychotherapy for erectile dysfunction is dual-sex therapy by Masters and Johnson.

 

Option D. Painful ejaculation: Painful ejaculation is pain felt during or after ejaculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation. Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once excitement has decreased, it is restarted. Hence, it is also known as stop-start technique. Another non-pharmacological treatment includes squeeze technique, where the female partner squeezes the coronal ridge of the glans, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

questions.text: A patient develops acute confusion and disorientation shortly after undergoing surgical intervention for a malignant tumor. Which of the following medications is typically the first-line treatment for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haloperidol

 

The patient is experiencing acute confusion and disorientation following surgery, which suggests the development of delirium. Delirium is a common postoperative complication, especially in older adults or those with significant medical conditions. The first-line treatment for delirium, particularly when it is accompanied by psychotic symptoms or severe agitation, is antipsychotic medication. Haloperidol is a traditional antipsychotic that is commonly used in this situation due to its efficacy in controlling these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, which is not typically used as a first-line treatment for delirium. It is more appropriate in the treatment of delirium tremens, which is a specific type of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal. In cases of delirium not related to alcohol withdrawal, lorazepam can actually worsen the confusion.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another antipsychotic that can be used to treat delirium, but it is not considered the first-line treatment as Haloperidol is more commonly preferred in acute cases.

 

Option D. Risperidone: Risperidone is also an antipsychotic that can be used in the management of delirium, but similar to Olanzapine, Haloperidol is generally preferred as the first-line option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haloperidol is the first-line treatment for delirium, especially when the patient exhibits significant agitation or psychotic symptoms following surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontotemporal dementia

 

Frontotemporal dementia, specifically the form associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (FTD-ALS complex), is caused by a hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9ORF72 gene. This expansion consists of GGGGCC (G4C2) repeats. It's one of the few known hexanucleotide repeat disorders and is a significant cause of both frontotemporal dementia and ALS.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fragile X Syndrome: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: Incorrect. There are two types of myotonic dystrophy. Type 1 is a trinucleotide (CTG) repeat disorder, while type 2 is a tetranucleotide (CCTG) repeat disorder.

 

Option D. Huntington disease: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, resulting in an expanded polyglutamine tract.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are functions of the superior oblique except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

Explanation:

 

Adduction is not a function of the superior oblique muscle. Adduction involves moving the eyeball towards the midline (towards the nose), and this movement is primarily mediated by the medial rectus muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abduction: The superior oblique muscle helps in the lateral movement of the eyeball, meaning it moves the eye away from the midline (abduction).

 

Option C. Depression: When the eye is adducted (turned towards the nose), the superior oblique muscle helps to depress the eyeball, moving it downward.

 

Option D. Intorsion: This is the primary function of the superior oblique muscle. Intorsion involves the rotation of the top of the eyeball towards the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles and is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV). The primary functions of the superior oblique muscle can be remembered using the mnemonic "SO-LID":

 

  • Superior Oblique
  • Lateral movement (Abduction)
  • Intorsion
  • Depression

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

 

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses enzyme-labeled antibodies and an enzymatic reaction to produce a detectable signal, usually a color change, and typically requires more time and equipment to perform.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect specific antigens or antibodies in a sample, requiring specialized equipment to visualize fluorescence.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Relies on a chemical reaction that produces light to detect antigens or antibodies, also requiring specialized equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunochromatographic tests, such as the HbsAg card test, provide a rapid, user-friendly, and effective means of testing for certain antigens or antibodies directly at the point of care. Their simplicity and speed make them invaluable tools in clinical settings, especially where quick decision-making is crucial.

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

 

  • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance. It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter.
  • It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horse shoe kidney: Characterized by a "hand-shake" or "flower vase" sign due to the fusion of the kidneys across the midline, typically seen in the lower lumbar region. This appearance does not match the image shown.

 

 

Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Often causes medial deviation of the ureters or a "silent kidney" if severe obstruction occurs. Not relevant to the observed sign.

 

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Affects male infants primarily and involves obstruction within the posterior urethra, leading to bladder and kidney changes. It does not cause the "cobra head" appearance seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureterocele should be suspected when an IVP reveals a "cobra head" sign, representing cystic dilation of the distal ureter. This condition can affect urinary drainage and lead to complications, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Easily curable or highly fatal disease

questions.text: What does it indicate about a disease if it has a high incidence but low prevalence? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (a) Easily curable or highly fatal disease

 

  • The relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed by the formula P = I × D, where P is prevalence, I is incidence, and D is duration of disease. 
  • When a disease has high incidence but low prevalence, it indicates that despite many new cases occurring (high incidence), the cases don't accumulate in the population (low prevalence). 
  • This happens when the duration of illness is short - either because patients recover quickly (easily curable) or die rapidly (highly fatal). Examples include food poisoning (rapid recovery) and homicides (rapidly fatal) which have virtually no prevalence despite having incidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Highly infectious: High infectiousness increases incidence (new cases) but doesn't necessarily result in low prevalence. Without rapid resolution, infectious diseases could still accumulate many cases, leading to high prevalence.

 

Option C. Chronic disease: Chronic diseases show the opposite pattern. Tuberculosis, for example, has a high prevalence rate relative to incidence because new cases keep occurring while old ones persist for months or years. Chronic diseases typically have high prevalence relative to incidence.

 

Option D. Poor reporting practices: This doesn't explain the epidemiological relationship between incidence and prevalence. Poor reporting would likely affect both measures, not create a specific pattern of high incidence with low prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mathematical relationship between prevalence, incidence and duration (P = I × D) demonstrates that diseases with short duration (due to rapid cure or death) will show high incidence but low prevalence in a population.

questions.text: According to International Health Regulations, yellow fever is unlikely to spread if the Aedes aegypti index is maintained below which percentage? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1%

 

The Aedes aegypti index is a house index defined as the percentage of houses and their premises in a limited well-defined area showing actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae. This index should not be more than 1% in towns and seaports in endemic areas to ensure freedom from yellow fever. It serves as an important surveillance parameter that helps determine the risk of yellow fever transmission in a given area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5%: This percentage refers to the Breteau index threshold, not the Aedes aegypti index. The Breteau index is a different measurement calculated as the number of positive containers per 100 houses inspected.

 

Option C. 8%: This percentage is not established as a threshold for any yellow fever vector control index in international guidelines.

 

Option D. 10%: This value is not recognized as a critical threshold for yellow fever prevention in relation to vector indices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Aedes aegypti index must be maintained below 1% in towns and seaports as part of the International Health Regulations to prevent yellow fever transmission, while other complementary measures like maintaining a Breteau index <5% and keeping airport perimeters free of Aedes breeding sites for at least 400 meters are also required.

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.text: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome results from a hemisection (partial transection) of the spinal cord, leading to a distinct pattern of neurological symptoms:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Motor Function: There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
    • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch: Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Pain and Temperature Sensation: Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side: Incorrect because fine touch is lost on the same side as the lesion, not the opposite.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side: Incorrect as pain and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option D. Only pain lost on the same side: Incorrect because pain sensation is lost on the opposite side and is associated with temperature loss as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemi section of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.

 

 

Functions of tracts involved -

 

Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception

 

Spinothalamic tract → contralateral pain and temperature sensation

 

Corticospinal tract → primary motor activity same side of the body.

questions.text: Pawn ball megakaryocytes are characteristic of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Explanation: 

 

Pawn ball megakaryocytes are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). These abnormal megakaryocytes have separated nuclear lobes instead of the normal single multi-lobated nucleus. The presence of these distinctive megakaryocytes is part of the dysmegakaryopoiesis that occurs in MDS, along with other features like ringed sideroblasts and pseudo-Pelger-Huet neutrophils. These morphological abnormalities reflect the underlying maturation defect at the level of myeloid stem cells that characterizes MDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. In ITP, megakaryocytes are typically normal or increased in number, but they do not show the characteristic pawn ball morphology. ITP is an immune-mediated disorder characterized by antibody destruction of platelets.

 

Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. TTP is characterized by microthrombi formation due to abnormally large von Willebrand factor multimers. The bone marrow findings in TTP do not typically include pawn ball megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol toxicity - This is incorrect. Chloramphenicol toxicity can cause bone marrow suppression and aplasia, but it is not specifically associated with pawn ball megakaryocytes. It tends to cause a general hypocellularity rather than dysplastic changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pawn ball megakaryocytes, with their distinctive separated nuclear lobes, are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes and reflect the dysplastic changes in megakaryopoiesis that are a hallmark of this group of disorders.

choices.text: Increased production of heat by liver

questions.text: Which physiological response is most likely to occur in a person exposed to high temperature while exercising vigorously to maintain internal body temperature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating and vasodilation in skin

 

When a person exercises vigorously, especially in high temperatures, the body needs to maintain its internal temperature within a safe range. During exercise, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to muscle contractions and relaxations. This process generates heat as a byproduct. To prevent overheating, the body employs two key mechanisms: sweating and vasodilation.

 

  • Sweating: Sweat glands produce sweat, which is released onto the skin surface. As the sweat evaporates, it helps cool the body down.
  • Vasodilation: Blood vessels in the skin widen (dilate), increasing blood flow to the skin. This allows more heat to be transferred from the body core to the skin, where it can be dissipated into the environment.

 

These processes help in losing excess heat and maintaining a stable internal body temperature during vigorous exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shivering and vasoconstriction in skin: These responses occur in cold environments to conserve heat. Shivering generates heat through muscle activity, and vasoconstriction reduces blood flow to the skin to minimize heat loss. These mechanisms are not activated in high temperatures.

 

Option C. Increased production of heat by liver: Although the liver does produce some heat, the question specifically asks for the physiological responses to high temperature and exercise. The primary responses are mechanisms to lose heat, not produce more.

 

Option D. Decreased heart rate: During vigorous exercise, the heart rate typically increases, not decreases, to supply muscles with more oxygen and nutrients. This response is part of the body's overall effort to support increased physical activity and manage heat stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During vigorous exercise in high temperatures, the body primarily responds by increasing sweating and vasodilation to dissipate heat and maintain a stable internal body temperature
